article.description:
It's a good thing Minnesota plays defense
better than it shoots free throws.
article.headline: Gophers hang on after missing four key free throws
article.linkText: Minnesota falters from line, but avoids upset in OT
article.story: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) -- It's a good thing Minnesota plays defense better than it shoots free throws. The Golden Gophers (No. 25 ESPN/USA Today) gave Arkansas-Little Rock two late chances to tie the game in overtime after four missed free throws. But their defense stopped both attempts as Minnesota beat the Trojans 86-84 on Tuesday night. ''Sure, when you miss four in a row at the end of the game it's going to bite you eventually,'' Gophers coach Dan Monson said. ''It didn't today, and we survived it.'' Rick Rickert led the Gophers with 25 points, two days after he was held scoreless in a loss at Nebraska. Minnesota, which fell out of the Associated Press Top 25 after Sunday's 80-60 loss to the Cornhuskers, clung to their two-point lead with 24.6 seconds remaining in overtime and Moe Hargrow at the foul line. After Hargrow missed his shots, Columbus Willis missed a jumper and the ball appeared to go out of bounds off Rickert. But the referees gave the ball to the Gophers, who got another chance to pad their lead when Kevin Burleson went to the line. But Burleson also missed his free throws with 6.5 seconds left, giving the Trojans one last chance. ''I'd have been a lot better on the nerves if they would have gone in,'' Gophers guard Ben Johnson said. Nick Zachery never got a good look at the basket as time expired. ''I wanted to run a little screen and fade on it, but we didn't get it,'' Trojan coach Porter Moser said. Minnesota escaped with another nail-biter of a win, their third buzzer-beating finish this season. ''We can't keep having these, man,'' Hargrow said. Little Rock (4-3) sent the game into overtime after Willis tied it at 76 with 9.3 seconds to go. The Gophers turned the ball over on the ensuing possession, but the Trojans couldn't get off a clean shot. Zachery had 13 points, all after halftime, and kept the Trojans in the game with a couple of 3-pointers in the overtime period. His 3-pointer with 3:37 to go in overtime tied the game at 79. Rickert followed with a tip off a miss and Moe Hargrow hit a three to give the Gophers an 84-79 lead. Zachery added his third 3-pointer of the game with 1:30 left, but Michael Bauer hit two free throws to give Minnesota an 86-82 lead at the 51.3 mark. Willis answered with a floater in the lane to complete the scoring. ''They played as hard as I could've ever hoped or expected,'' Moser said. But the loss still hurt. ''You can't just be satisfied that you came close,'' Moser said. ''We wanted to win this game.'' Little Rock's smaller players created several mismatches. Most noticeably, guards Jibrahn Ike and Tony Travis, both Minneapolis natives, hurt Minnesota from the perimeter. Ike, who starred at St. Anthony High School, led Little Rock with 20 points on 8-of-15 shooting. He made 4 of 8 from 3-point range but fouled out with the score tied 71-all. Travis had 14 points. ''I know a lot of people are going to say, 'What went wrong?''' Monson said. ''I look at what went right. We were fortunate to win that game and I thought we played pretty good.'' Johnson had 14 points for the Gophers, while Hargrow added 13. Jerry Holman and Bauer each had 11 points for Minnesota. Holman had a couple of blocks late in the game to prevent some easy layups for Little Rock, bringing chants of ''Je-rry! Je-rry!'' from the crowd. After trailing 46-44 at halftime, the Gophers scored five unanswered points to regain the lead. But Little Rock took advantage of a couple of turnovers by Rickert and answered with a three-point play by Danny McHall, and consecutive 3-pointers by Mark Green and Tony Travis to take a 55-51 lead at the 15:32 mark.
